section.title: About build systems in general
section.para: As software is becoming increasingly complex, the process of creating software is becoming more complex too. Today's software uses various languages, requires various compilers, and the input data is spread into many files.

Software is now used to express the process of building software, it can take the form of simple scripts (shell scripts, makefiles), of compilers (CMake, qmake), or complete applications (Scons, Waf). The term "build system" is used to design the tools used to build applications.

section.title: The Waf approach
section.para: Build systems make assumptions on the business problems they are trying to solve, and are typically limited where it comes to processing other languages. For example, Ant is better than Make for processing Java applications, but is more limited than make for processing simple c applications.

There are so many different languages that creating a build system to support all the possible business rules out-of-the-box is likely to be difficult. It looks much more interesting to make one which can be extended easily.

The Waf approach is to provide a minimalistic and very flexible framework, and packaged with a significant amount of business rules to be usable for most projects, and recipes for the most complex scenarios. The main goals of waf are: the flexibility, the performance, and the features.

section.title: Objectives of this book
section.para: The objectives of this book is to expose the use of the Waf build system though the use of Waf in practice, the description of the Waf extension system, and detailed review of the Waf internals. (TODO: give a quick reference on the chapter organization)
